items.title: BaseSSHTunnelForwarderError: Could not establish session to SSH gateway
items.body:
While trying to SSH to the MYSQL database using a secure SSHTunnel, I get the following error:

```
   1292         if not self.is_active:
   1293             self._raise(BaseSSHTunnelForwarderError,
-> 1294                         reason='Could not establish session to SSH gateway')
   1295         for _srv in self._server_list:
   1296             thread = threading.Thread(

   1098     def _raise(self, exception=BaseSSHTunnelForwarderError, reason=None):
   1099         if self._raise_fwd_exc:
-> 1100             raise exception(reason)
   1101         else:
   1102             self.logger.error(repr(exception(reason)))

BaseSSHTunnelForwarderError: Could not establish session to SSH gateway
```

I am able to ssh to the Database from my SQL workbench. I am also able to connect to the database by ssh'ing from the terminal. The database is up and running but I am not able to make a secure connection through SSHTunnelForwarder using Python3.7. Here is the code I am using to make the secure ssh connection.

```
ssh_server =  SSHTunnelForwarder(
     (server_ip, 22),
     ssh_private_key="./.ssh/XXXX.pem",
     ssh_username="XXXX",
      remote_bind_address=(server_remote_bind_address, 3306)
    )
```
I get the error when I try to start the ssh server by executing `ssh_server.start()`

I'm using:
```
sshtunnel==0.1.5
Python 3.7
```

items.title: Hangs with Python 3.7
items.body:
I'm using SSHTunnelForwarder with Python 3.7. After finishing my work, I run `server.stop()` and hangs.

I believe it caused by `socketserver.ThreadingMixIn`
https://docs.python.org/3.7/library/socketserver.html#socketserver.ThreadingMixIn
> Changed in version 3.7: socketserver.ForkingMixIn.server_close() and socketserver.ThreadingMixIn.server_close() now waits until all child processes and non-daemonic threads complete. Add a new socketserver.ForkingMixIn.block_on_close class attribute to opt-in for the pre-3.7 behaviour.

Here's my work around. I changed the attribute `server._server_list[0].block_on_close = False`, and it behave like usual. It closed normally and not being hang.

 I'm not sure if setting `block_on_close = False` is a good way or not.

Issue #135 may have the same cause.

items.title: SSH key format
items.body:
I noticed an error whilst using SSH key based authentication. 

`  File "/.../.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 905, in __init__                                                                                                                    
    logger=self.logger                                                                                                                                                                                           
  File "/.../.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 1096, in _consolidate_auth                                                                                                          
    raise ValueError('No password or public key available!')   
`

After doing some digging I found that this was due to the format of the RSA key. Apparently the standard output from ssh-keygen is not supported.

As a workaround you can use:

`ssh-keygen -m pem ...`

Please could you modify to automatically convert?

items.title: Paramiko threads don't exit
items.body:
Hi There.
When I'm running on SSH tunnel, on python 2.7.14 in windows, my Paramiko threads aren't existing and keep running forever, at the end of the program. 

in example:
```
from sshtunnel import SSHTunnelForwarder
from sqlalchemy import create_engine

ssh_server = SSHTunnelForwarder(ssh_address_or_host=('address', int(22)),
                                ssh_username='usr',
                                ssh_pkey='/sshkey/path',
                                ssh_password=None,
                                ssh_private_key_password=None,
                                remote_bind_address=('127.0.0.1', 3306),
                                threaded=False)
ssh_server.start()
engine = create_engine('mysql+pymysql://usr:pwd@127.0.0.1:{}/db'.format(ssh_server.local_bind_port))
engine.connect()
for i in range(1, 5):
    cur = engine.execute('select * from db.tbl limit 10;')
    print cur.fetchall()

ssh_server.close()
```

The ssh_server.close() doesn't close the paramiko thread at the end of the program, so it stays alive forever. 

Thanks

items.title: Python process hangs indefinitely when error is raised
items.body:
If I start an SSH tunnel and some code crashes before `server.stop()` is called, then my python process hangs indefinitely. I'm get this behavior on Ubuntu 16.04 running Python 2.7.12 as well as OS X 10.12.6 running Python 2.7.15, both running sshtunnel v 0.1.2 from `pip install sshtunnel`. I also tested v0.1.4 that I cloned today from this repository into a fresh virtual environment on OS X. It hangs in all cases.

Minimal example:
```
from sshtunnel import SSHTunnelForwarder
server = SSHTunnelForwarder(
    'hostname.com',
    ssh_username="user",
    ssh_pkey="/path/to/id_rsa",
    remote_bind_address=('127.0.0.1', 5432)
)
server.start()
print(server.local_bind_port)  # show assigned local port
raise ValueError('random error')

server.stop()
```

When I run the example, I get:
```
$ python sshtunnel_then_error.py 
45528
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "foo.py", line 12, in <module>
    raise ValueError('random error')
ValueError: random error
```
At which point the program hangs indefinitely. 

I tried working around with atexit, but to no avail. Snippets from that experiment:
```
import atexit
def _cleanup():
    global server
    try:
        server.stop()
    except:
        pass
atexit.register(_cleanup)
```
Any ideas for fixes or work-arounds? 
Thanks!

items.title: UWSGI Thread Tunnel Error
_check_tunnel fails when using adresses other than 127.0.0.1
items.body:
Hello, 

First of all thank you for this great library !!

In `_check_tunnel(self, _srv)`, to avoid Windows error when trying to connect to `0.0.0.0`, use of `127.0.0.1` is forced:

```python
# Windows raises WinError 10049 if trying to connect to `0.0.0.0`
s.connect(('127.0.0.1', _srv.local_port))
```
When setting up tunnels on addresses picked from `127.0.0.1/8` (loopback ip addres range) (e.g. `127.1.1.1`), `_check_tunnel(self, _srv)` still uses `127.0.0.1` instead of `127.1.1.1` which gives wrong result (a `DOWN` status instead of an `UP`)

Following code would allow to correctly check those tunnels:

```python
# Windows raises WinError 10049 if trying to connect to 0.0.0.0
addr = '127.0.0.1' if _srv.local_address == '0.0.0.0' else _srv.local_host
s.connect((addr, _srv.local_port))
```

Regards

items.title: Question: way to catch server unavailable on remote
items.body:
Hi

I have this code:
```
self.tunnel = SSHTunnelForwarder(
    (self.remote_host, self.remote_port),
    ssh_username=self.ssh_username,
    ssh_password=self.ssh_password,
    remote_bind_address=(u'127.0.0.1', self.forward_port)
 )
 self.tunnel.start()

self.socket = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
```

items.title: SSHTunnelForwarder.daemon_forward_servers is not respected
items.body:
Opening this issue to get any thoughts before I do a PR.

Test case:

In ipython, construct a tunnel using:
```
tun = SSHTunnelForwarder((ssh_host, 22), ssh_username=user,
                              remote_bind_address=remote, local_bind_address=('127.0.0.1',),
                              ssh_pkey=ssh_key)
tun.daemon_forward_servers = True
tun.daemon_transport = True
tun.start()

In [12]: [(repr(t), t.isDaemon()) for t in threading.enumerate()]
Out[12]:
[('<_MainThread(MainThread, started 140736862168000)>', False),
 ('<HistorySavingThread(IPythonHistorySavingThread, started 123145316188160)>',
  True),
 ('<paramiko.Transport at 0xf68c048 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (active; 1 open channel(s))>',
  True),
 ('<Thread(Srv-61825, started daemon 123145326698496)>', True),
 ('<Thread(Thread-282, started daemon 123145337208832)>', False)]
```

That last one should also be a daemon. The workaround is to set `_ThreadingForwardServer.daemon_threads=True`.

Questions:

* Is there a particular reason to have a global `DAEMON`?
  * It looks like public interface, but you can't update it once classes are initialized.
  * And, yuck, globals.
* Is there any benefit to having a separate `daemon_forward_servers` and `daemon_transport` field?

Proposal:
1. replace `DAEMON` with literal `False`
  * Still want a default to protect from crashes.
2. `_make_ssh_forward_server` sets `ssh_forward_server.daemon_threads = self.daemon_forward_servers`
3. Replace `SSHTunnelForwarder.daemon_*` with `.daemon`.

items.title: Issues with CLI usage
items.body:
Let's compare a `ssh` and the equivalent `sshtunnel` command:
```
ssh -p 2222                             \
    -L localhost:40000:remote_host:3306 \
    user@proxy_host
```
```
sshtunnel -p 2222                      \
          -L localhost:40000           \
          -R remote_host:3306          \
          -U user                      \
          proxy_host
```

1. `sshtunnel` uses `-L` for local port forwarding (like `ssh`) and `-R` for the second part of the local port forwarding. `ssh` uses `-R` for remote port forwarding - which is something completely different.

2. `sshtunnel` has `-x proxy_host:proxy_port` . When `-x` is used, `-p SSH_PORT` and `ssh_address` are silently ignored.

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [sshtunnel](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/sshtunnel), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install sshtunnel with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: Script won't exit after one of the loaded ssh keys fails authentication
items.body:
This is similar to #72. What's different here is that several ssh keys are loaded. The first key used fails authentication. The second key passes. Example script:

```
import threading
import sshtunnel

with sshtunnel.open_tunnel(
    '<remotehost>',
    debug_level='DEBUG',
    remote_bind_address=('localhost', 5432),
) as server:
    print(server.local_bind_port)

# [t.close() for t in threading.enumerate() if t.__class__.__name__ == "Transport"]

print('FINISH!')
```

Prints out the following but never exits to the shell:

```
2016-10-21 11:16:55,045| INF | MainThrea/0981@sshtunnel | 3 keys loaded from agent
2016-10-21 11:16:55,045| INF | MainThrea/0901@sshtunnel | Connecting to gateway: <remotehost>:22 as user 'username'
2016-10-21 11:16:55,045| DEB | MainThrea/0904@sshtunnel | Concurrent connections allowed: True
2016-10-21 11:16:55,045| DEB | MainThrea/1284@sshtunnel | Trying to log in with key: 01234567890123456789012345678901
2016-10-21 11:16:55,133| DEB | MainThrea/1293@sshtunnel | Authentication error
2016-10-21 11:16:55,133| WAR | MainThrea/1333@sshtunnel | Server is not started. Please .start() first!
2016-10-21 11:16:55,133| DEB | MainThrea/1351@sshtunnel | Transport is closed
2016-10-21 11:16:55,134| DEB | MainThrea/1284@sshtunnel | Trying to log in with key: 98765432109876543210987654321098
2016-10-21 11:16:55,222| INF | Srv-37096/1318@sshtunnel | Opening tunnel: 0.0.0.0:37096 <> localhost:5432
37096
2016-10-21 11:16:55,222| INF | MainThrea/1337@sshtunnel | Shutting down tunnel ('0.0.0.0', 37096)
2016-10-21 11:16:55,323| INF | Srv-37096/1324@sshtunnel | Tunnel: 0.0.0.0:37096 <> localhost:5432 released
2016-10-21 11:16:55,442| DEB | MainThrea/1351@sshtunnel | Transport is closed
FINISH!
```

And similar #72 if the second to last line which explicitly closes the paramiko.Transport threads is uncommented then the script exits correctly.

Using sshtunnel 0.1.1, paramiko 1.17.1

items.title: Ignore error
items.body:
I am using this package in [my package](https://github.com/basnijholt/hpc05) to use `ipyparallel` with our university cluster.

items.title: Script won't exit because paramiko thread is still running
items.body:
The following script works and "FINISH" is printed, but it never exits to the shell:

``` python
import threading

from sshtunnel import SSHTunnelForwarder

with SSHTunnelForwarder(
    "localhost",
    ssh_username="localuser",
    ssh_password="localpass",
    remote_bind_address=('127.0.0.1', 5984),
    local_bind_address=('127.0.0.1', 9000)
) as server:

    print(server.local_bind_port)
    # these don't help
    # server.stop()
    # server.close()

# [t.close() for t in threading.enumerate() if t.__class__.__name__ == "Transport"]

print('FINISH!')
```

Python is waiting on threads to finish, but they never do. After running this script in iPython I can see the threads:

``` python
threading.enumerate()
[<_MainThread(MainThread, started 140735243972608)>,
 <HistorySavingThread(IPythonHistorySavingThread, started 123145307557888)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3880470 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3874630 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3191ba8 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3874550 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (active; 0 open channel(s))>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3191c88 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x387bac8 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3803e48 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>,
 <paramiko.Transport at 0x3874f60 (cipher aes128-ctr, 128 bits) (connected; awaiting auth)>]
```

If I uncomment the last line which explicitly closes the paramiko.Transport threads, the script exits correctly. It seems like I'm missing something, but even so this default behavior is confusing.

items.title: When connecting with a proxy command, AttributeError is raised from erroneously calling connect() on paramiko.proxy.ProxyCommand
items.body:
In sshtunnel.py, in _get_transport(), the code erroneously calls connect() on _socket irregardless of the existence of self.ssh_proxy. This leads to an AttributeError when, for example, a config file has a proxy command. The reason for this is that in this case, _socket is not an instance of socket.socket but paramiko.proxy.ProxyCommand, which has no method connect() and should be passed directly into paramiko.Transport.

I think the change that needs to be made is moving lines 1022-1023 under the else clause, as it was the case with 0.0.8.2.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 116, in <module>
    remote_bind_address=(mysql_host, int(mysql_port))) as server:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 1478, in **enter**
    self._raise(exception=exc_class, reason=exc, traceback=tb)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 1007, in _raise
    raise exception(reason, traceback)
AttributeError: (AttributeError("'ProxyCommand' object has no attribute 'connect'",), <traceback object at 0x7f4c23b98998>)

```
def _get_transport(self):
    """ Return the SSH transport to the remote gateway """
    if self.ssh_proxy:
        if isinstance(self.ssh_proxy, paramiko.proxy.ProxyCommand):
            proxy_repr = repr(self.ssh_proxy.cmd[1])
        else:
            proxy_repr = repr(self.ssh_proxy)
        self.logger.debug('Connecting via proxy: {0}'.format(proxy_repr))
        _socket = self.ssh_proxy
    else:
        _socket = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    **_socket.settimeout(SSH_TIMEOUT)**
    **_socket.connect((self.ssh_host, self.ssh_port))**
    transport = paramiko.Transport(_socket)
    transport.set_keepalive(self.set_keepalive)
    transport.use_compression(compress=self.compression)
    transport.daemon = self.daemon_transport
```

items.title: port is incorrectly read from ssh config file as a string, leading to AssertionError: PORT is not a number
items.body:
When initializing SSHTunnelForwarder() with the default ssh config file, an AssertionError is raised:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test_ssh.py", line 99, in <module>
    remote_bind_address=(mysql_host, int(mysql_port))) as server:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 877, in **init**
    check_port(self.ssh_port)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 76, in check_port
    assert isinstance(port, int), 'PORT is not a number'
AssertionError: PORT is not a number

Looking through the code, it seems that in _read_ssh_config(), ssh_port is taken "as is" from hostname_info. hostname_info, in turn, is the result of paramiko.SSHConfig().lookup() which returns port as string. Thus int assertion fails on ssh_port.

I was able to fix the issue by simply converting ssh_port to int in _read_ssh_config():
sshtunnel.py, line 911: ssh_port = ssh_port or hostname_info.get('port')
change to 
sshtunnel.py, line 911: ssh_port = ssh_port or int(hostname_info.get('port'))

Let me know if I'm missing something. Thanks.

items.title: fails to get local interfaces if cannot resolve local hostname
items.body:
Hey,
I noticed that for some reason, SSHTunnelForwarder would always throw an exception regardless of the parameters, 

`socket.gaierror: [Errno 8] nodename nor servname provided, or not known`

it was caused by _get_local_interfaces trying to resolve the local hostname (in my case, Ich) and failing (probably just a bad /etc/hosts file or something, not really sure)

anyway, this caused me a couple of hours of frustration but i eventually figured out that if i replace 

```
      local_if = socket.gethostbyname_ex(socket.gethostname())[-1]
```

with 

```
      try:
        local_if = socket.gethostbyname_ex(socket.gethostname())[-1]
    except:
        local_if = []
```

it will handle this exception.

I can make a pull request if you like.

items.title: sshtunnel 0.0.8 doesn't work Windows
items.body:
Release 0.0.8 won't work on Windows.

Specifically, `socketserver` doesn't expose `UnixStreamServer` on Windows. Since `_UnixStreamForwardServer` inherits from `socketserver.UnixStreamServer`, merely importing `sshtunnel` results in an Exception being raised on Windows.

items.title: Catch “Could not open connection to gateway”
items.body:
Every now and then setting up a tunnel using sshtunnel.py fails because the gateway (ssh_host) complains the first time I connect to it. I would like to give it a few retries before giving up:

```
for attempt in range(5):
    try:
        forwarder.start()
    except Exception, e:
        print 'Error (trying again in five seconds):\n' + format(e.message))
        time.sleep(5)
    else:
        break
else:
    print 'Failed to setup a connection to the gateway'
    sys.exit(1)
```

However, the exception is not caught. I took a peek in the sshtunnel.py code and found that the [following](https://github.com/pahaz/sshtunnel/blob/94c2bef94b59494a287fe07158baa103efefaab5/sshtunnel.py#L669) code catches the related Paramiko exception:

```
except paramiko.ssh_exception.AuthenticationException:
    self.logger.error('Could not open connection to gateway')
    return
```

Does this make it impossible to catch a 'Could not open connection to gateway' exception?

items.title: New pip release for ssh_private_key_password
items.body:
I am using sshtunnel with certificates with passwords. It would be awesome to have a new pip release including the ssh_private_key_password code that was merged 15 days ago.

Thanks.

items.title: Please add option to set SSH idle timeout.
Add option to not read ~/.ssh/config & pass private key through the API
items.body: This would be useful when running unit tests so that all data are in the test suite. This entails passing `ssh_private_key` as str/bytes in `__init__`. Are you open to pull requests if I do that? Thx.

items.title: If debug_level argument is passed to constructor then unknown argument error is raised
items.body:
``` python
SSHTunnelForwarder( '1.2.3.4', 22, debug_level='ERROR')
```

Results in an error (similar to this):

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/runpy.py", line 170, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/Users/user/pyenvs/application/__main__.py", line 213, in <module>
    args.profile
  File "/Users/user/pyenvs/application/ssh_tools/ssh.py", line 47, in forward_necessary_ports
    debug_level='ERROR'
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 552, in __init__
    raise ValueError('Unknown arguments {0:!r}'.format(kwargs))
TypeError: non-empty format string passed to object.__format__
```

debug_error is a configurable kwarg so this shouldn't be the case. A pop occurring after the argument is read should occur

items.title: Default logger displays ssh password
items.body: I'm using getpass to allow the user to enter his ssh password on the command-line, before starting the tunnel. However this is then logged in plain text by the logger (DEBUG level). I can avoid this by enforcing a higher logging level but it would be safer not displaying it at all by default.

items.title: Support -v -vv and -vvv options for CLI
items.body: associated with https://github.com/pahaz/sshtunnel/issues/22

items.title: Default loglevel or DEBUG is too high, annoying
items.body:
Suggest changing DEBUG -> CRITICAL for general sanity.

``` python
DEFAULT_LOGLEVEL = 'CRITICAL'  # Default level for logging, if no logger passed
```

items.title: error connecting
items.body:
Hi,

There is my code:

```
from sshtunnel import SSHTunnelForwarder

server = SSHTunnelForwarder(
        ssh_address=(config.SSH_HOST,config.SSH_PORT),
        ssh_username=config.SSH_USER,
        ssh_password=config.SSH_PASSWORD,
        remote_bind_address=(config.SSH_REMOTE_HOST, config.SSH_REMOTE_PORT)
        )
server.start()
print server.local_bind_port
```

And when execute them, i'm receive this error

  File "tunel.py", line 34, in <module>
    server.start()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sshtunnel.py", line 664, in start
    for _srv in self._server_list
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'daemon'

Can you help me?
